filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the republication of electronic editions of the Thomas Butts and John Linnell series of Blake’s water color illustrations of the Book of Job and the sketchbook of preliminary pencil drawings for his Job engravings. These three series were previously published in our Preview mode, one that provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote (which provides detailed descriptions of Blake’s images). With this republication, those functions now become available, along with our new Related Works feature giving access to related materials through active links on the work index pages and the Show Me menu on the object view pages. Blake’s Job engravings have been previously published with Image Search and Inote capabilities.
With this republication, the Archive now includes fully searchable reproductions of all four series of Job designs, among Blake’s greatest achievements as a visual artist. Thus, characters pictured in the designs, such as Bildad, Eliphaz, and of course Job’s wife, can be searched and located in all four series. The Archive’s Image Search menu also includes a great many lesser motifs, figure types, postures and gestures. In coming months, we will publish similarly updated versions of other works presently in Preview mode, including Blake’s nine series of water colors illustrating the poetry of John Milton.
The Archive recently added a new set of scholarly tools that should prove particularly useful when studying Blake’s Job designs. These tools, known collectively as our Related Works system, are designed to show relationships among works and individual objects in the Archive. They function at two levels. First, work index pages now include active links to related materials in the Archive. Thus, researchers can move easily from any given Job series to any other series. Second, the Show Me menu on object view pages now includes Related Works in the Archive. Like the work-level menu, this list includes active links to related designs and is meant to allow study of the related materials side by side. For example, researchers can move quickly from Blake’s engraving of Behemoth and Leviathan to its drawing in the sketchbook and study how Blake developed his design from preliminary sketch to finished engraving.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.
September 2006:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of electronic editions of the Linnell set of Blake's water color illustrations to The Book of Job and the sketchbook containing Blake's reduced drawings preparatory for the Job engravings. The sketchbook is reproduced complete and in color for the first time. These two important sets of Job illustrations join the Butts set of water colors and the engravings, both previously published in the Archive. Thus, the Archive now includes all four series of Job illustrations. The engravings are fully searchable. The Linnell set of water colors and the sketchbook are presented in our Preview mode, one that provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote (our image annotation program).
Blake's pictorial engagements with The Book of Job extended over many decades. His first efforts were a small group of wash drawings of the mid-1780s showing Job in his misery with his wife and three friends. Another version of this subject appears among the emblem series that Blake sketched in his Notebook, but the composition appearing in the wash drawings culminated in the large intaglio etching/engraving, "Job," which Blake listed in his advertisement To the Public of 10 October 1793. This print may have stimulated Blake's chief patron, Thomas Butts, to commission a tempera painting, Job and His Daughters, c. 1799-1800 and, about six years later, a series of nineteen water colors illustrating the story of Job (the so-called "Butts set"). In 1821, Blake and his new patron John Linnell borrowed the water colors from Butts. Linnell traced the series and Blake colored them (the so-called "Linnell set"). Blake also added two more compositions to this later group and added versions of these same compositions to the earlier group, so that both sets now have twenty-one designs. The Linnell set led directly to his commission for the engravings. These began as a series of reduced sketches executed in 1823; the engravings themselves, with a title page added, were not finished and published until 1826.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible through the continuing support of the Library of Congress, the Institute for Advanced Technology in the Humanities at the University of Virginia, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and by the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

desc.related: These sketches, preparatory for the engravings, may be related to the female figure (one of Job’s daughters) kneeling to the left of Job’s wife in this water color.
This sketch, preparatory for the engravings, may be related, albeit distantly, to the foliage on the large central tree in Objects 1 and 21 in the Linnell series of water colors.

These sketches, preparatory for the engravings, may be related to the dog with its head resting on a sheep in the center foreground in Object 1 in the Linnell series of water colors or to the dog with its head resting on the ground in the center foreground in Object 21 in the Linnell series of water colors.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job, his wife, and his sons and daughters sit and kneel in attitudes of prayer before a large, central tree (perhaps an oak). Job and his wife have open books (perhaps Bibles) on their laps; all seven sons hold shepherd's crooks. The son farthest to the right also has a harp; a larger harp, a mandolin (or some such stringed instrument), a tambourine, and four horned instruments hang in the tree above the heads of Job and his wife. A musical horn dangles by the side of the son farthest to the left. Seven sheep, and what may be a sheepdog, lie in the grassy foreground. Just behind the human figures is a large flock of sheep, visible left and right; behind the sheep are (from left to right) a clump of trees, a Gothic building (probably a church), an additional structure on the far left, and four tents. Above the background hills and mountains are a radiant sun (left) that may be rising or setting, a star or planet, and a crescent moon (right).

component.illusobjdesc: Job sits among his family on the right side of the central tree. He has long hair, a beard and wears a gown, and faces forward with his head turned slightly to the left. His eyes are raised. He holds an open book in his lap. Like most of the other figures in the scene, Job may be praying.

On the far left of the group of figures is one of Job's sons. He kneels while holding a shepherd's crook. Like most of the other figures in the scene, he may be praying. A small musical horn dangles at his right thigh. He wears a long gown and his hair is short and curly. He faces half-way between forward and to the right, with his head lowered slightly. His bare right foot, and the bare heel of his left foot, are pictured.

The figure second from the left, one of Job's sons, kneels and prays, palms together. He is gowned and faces half-way between forward and to the right. His hair is short and a little curly; he holds a shepherd's crook under his left arm. His head is raised slightly.

The figure third from the left, one of Job's sons, kneels and prays, hands clasped together. He is gowned and faces half-way between forward and to the right. He is bearded and his hair is long. Like his brother to the left, he is holding a shepherd's crook under his left arm.

We see only the face and part of the upper chest of Job's son fourth from the left. He is probably kneeling, like his brothers, and may be praying. He faces half-way between forward and to the right, with his head slightly lowered. The top of a shepherd's crook is visible above his head.

One of Job's daughters kneels in prayer between the group of four brothers on the left and Job's wife. She wears a long gown; her hair is short and curly. Her body faces to the right, and her head is turned slightly down. Her bare feet are prominent.

One of Job's daughters kneels between her parents in the center of the design. Like her sister to the left, she may be praying. She is gowned and has long hair. We see her from behind; her bare feet are prominent.

One of Job's daughters kneels just to the right of Job and left of the group of three sons on the right. Like her sisters, she may be praying. She is gowned and has her arms crossed over her chest, and the fingers of her right hand are spread apart slightly. She faces left with her head tilted slightly down. Her long(?) hair is gathered into a bun; her bare left foot is prominent.

One of Job's sons kneels in prayer, palms together, far right in the group of figures. He is gowned; his hair is short and curly. He holds a shepherd's crook, apparently between his bent arms; a lyre dangles below his left arm. He faces to the left and his bare left foot is prominent.

One of Job's sons kneels in prayer, hands clasped together, second from the right in the group of figures. He is gowned, bearded, and his hair is short and curly. He faces half-way between forward and to the left and holds his shepherd's crook under his right arm.

One of Job's sons kneels third from the right in the group of figures. He is gowned, bearded, and has short, curly hair. Like his brothers to the right, he may be praying. He faces half-way between forward and to the left and holds his shepherd's crook with both hands.

The group of foreground animals includes (left to right), a ram, four sheep, a dog with its muzzle resting on the hindquarters of a sheep apparently facing left, a ram, and perhaps the back of a fifth sheep. All are lying prone; the dog, the sheep below his head, and both rams have their eyes closed and may be sleeping. The rams display looped and spiral-like horns.
A small mound of earth appears below the central tree and kneeling figures.
The foreground landscape would appear to be covered with tufts of grass, particularly prominent below the sheep.
The upper center of the composition is anchored by a large and leafy tree, probably an oak.
A large flock of sheep is pictured in the middle distance on the left side of the composition. They are all standing, some with heads down to eat the grass.
A large flock of sheep is pictured in the middle distance on the right side of the composition. The front-most sheep is lying prone. Second from the front is a ram with twisted, spiral-like horns.
A small clump of leafy trees appears in the background near the left margin of the design and the large gothic building.

A large Gothic building, perhaps a church, appears in the background on the left. It is decorated with a tower, spires, and a central pointed arch that probably represents a doorway. The structure on the far left, with one archway and several spires, may be a separate building. The buildings are probably made of stone.
Two tents appear in the middle distance just right of the large tree. Another group of tents appears far right under the crescent moon.
A cluster of leafy plants, probably bushes or small trees, appears between the sheep and the tents along the right margin.
A line of hills, with a larger mountain on the right, define the horizon.
A rising or setting sun bears a fragmented inscription of the Lord's Prayer inside its arc. Its radiance forms beams of light.
A few words from the Lord's Prayer are inscribed within the sun: "Our Father which art / in Hea ... Name".
A crescent moon appears in the sky on the right.
A star or planet (possibly Venus, given the rising or setting sun far left) appears above the mountain peak left of the crescent moon.

A group of seven musical instruments hang in the tree above the heads of Job and his wife. They are, from left to right, a horn with a looped, spiral-like body, a tambourine, a mandolin (or some such stringed instrument), a large triangular harp, two horns, and a trumpet.

lg.l: Our Father which artLines 1-2 are lightly written in pencil within the small portion of the sun's disc appearing just above the distant mountains on the left.
in HeaNameVery probably a fragmentary transcription of words from the Lord's Prayer, "in Heaven, hallowed be thy Name."

desc.objtitle: Satan before the Throne of God, Object 2 (Butlin 551.2)

objnote.p: The original water color was last recorded in the possession of an American living in Europe, but is now untraced. The image presented here was produced from the color collotype reproduction published in *Illustrations of the Book of Job by William Blake*, introduction by Laurence Binyon and Geoffrey Keynes (New York: The Pierpont Morgan Library, 1935).

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job sits with his family lower center, holding a book or tablet and gesturing with his right hand. His wife is to the left, holding on open book on her lap. Six of Job's children sit, lie, and stand on the right; one holds a scroll and another a book. The figures are seated on what appears to be a long, low bench. A dog sleeps beneath the bench on which several of Job's children sit. Two winged angels hover lower left; both hold scrolls. Behind the family group are two trees with vines and clusters of grapes entwined around their trunks. A flock of sheep grazes in the left middle distance. Another complex figure group appears in the heavens above, partly contained within cloud bands left and right. At the top sits God with radiance behind his head and upper body and an open book on his lap. He points downward with his right index finger to Satan, who hovers, striding vigorously to the left, in flames. Also in the fire are the faces of Job and his wife. Four angels hover on the left side of the group; one deposits a book before God's throne-like chair, while another holds an open book. These figures are balanced by a group of five on the right, including an angel placing a scroll before God and another holding a scroll.

component.illusobjdesc: The foreground is grassy.

Job sits with his family lower center. His hair and beard are long; his bare feet appear beneath the hem of his gown. He faces forward with his head turned to the left, and holds a book or tablet between his left hand and left knee. With his right hand he gestures downward and to the right, fingers spread. His head and eyes are turned slightly upward.
Job holds a book or tablet.

Job's wife sits to the left of her husband. She is gowned and her hair is long. She faces forward, with her head and eyes turned slightly to the right and downward. Her arms are bent and she holds an open book on her lap.
Job's wife holds an open book on her lap.

Two winged and youthful angels hover lower left. The front-most angel is gowned and holds a scroll in his upturned palms. His hair is short and curly; his body faces forward and slightly to the right, and his head is turned to the right. Both feet are visible beneath the hem of his gown.
The two winged and youthful angels, lower left, hold scrolls in their hands.

Two winged and youthful angels hover lower left. The rear angel, almost covered by his companion, is gowned and holds a scroll in his upturned palm. His hair is long; his body faces forward and to the right, his head is turned to the right, and his eyes look downward. His bare feet are visible.

One of Job's youthful sons sits, half-reclining, just to the right of his father. His hair is short and curly. He faces forward with his head turned to the left, and is nude except for the bit of drapery covering his lap and right shoulder. He holds a scroll in his left hand. His right leg is bent at the knee before him, his left leg extended to the right. His bare right foot is clearly pictured.

One of Job's daughters is the second figure to the right of her father. She is seated and half-reclining, with her left arm at her side. She appears to be nude, and faces forward with her head turned slightly to the left. Her hair is long and curly.

A young boy appears as the third figure to the right of Job. We see only his head (facing forward and slightly to the left) and possibly his shoulders, which might indicate he is wearing a gown. He is probably sitting, like the two figures to the left.

A youthful and nude male stands, facing left, as the second figure from the right in the foreground. His right leg is bent at the knee, his left arm is bent at 45 degrees, and he holds a book in his left hand. His hair is short and curly.

Behind and to the right of the seated female is another female figure, of whom only the head and shoulders are visible. She is gowned, has long hair, and faces forward with her head turned to the right.

A gowned female figure with long hair is pictured at the edge of the right margin. She is partially hidden by the nude young man in front of her, with only her head, shoulders, and long gown visible. She faces and looks to the left.
A flock of sheep graze on the grass between the hovering angels and Job's wife in the near middle-distance.
A grassy(?) hill is pictured above the sheep who graze between the hovering angels and Job's wife.
Job, his wife, and four members of his family sit on an odd bench-like seat with a dog lying under it.
A dog, lying prone and facing left, sleeps beneath the bench on which Job's children sit.
Two trees bearing leaves appear in the middle distance right of Job. Both trees have vines, which bear leaves and clusters of grapes, entwined around the trunk.

Cloud bands, left and right, define the interior spaces of the upper part of the composition. The clouds on the left extend downward to the area between the left margin and the hovering angels left of Job and his family; there are also clouds behind Satan's right foot.

God, enthroned, sits at the top of the design. Radiance and beams of light surround his head and upper body; his hair and beard are long. His bare right foot appears beneath the hem of his gown. He holds (with his left hand) an open book on his lap, and points downward with his right hand and extended index finger.
A few clouds appear above the head of the seated female, the second figure right of Job.
Radiance surrounds God's head and upper body.
God sits, enthroned, on a chair or seat, apparently made of stone. It is raised on what appears to be a plinth, perhaps with at least one step.

Four nude angels hover to the left of God. The upper-most angel faces right and slightly down; his posture suggests that he may be bowing. We see only the side and back of his head and his torso; his hair is long.
Four nude angels hover to the left of God. The angel second from the top faces right and slightly down. His hair appears to be short; he may be bowing.

Four nude angels hover to the left of God. The third angel from the top faces right and slightly down, with his body facing partially forward. His hair is short and curly. His arms are extended horizontally towards the right. His posture suggests that he is bowing before God, and has just offered, with the fingers of his left hand spread apart, a book towards which he appears to be looking. His legs are together. His genitals are clearly visible.
Four angels hover to the left of God. A closed book appears just right of the extended hands of the angel third from the top.

Four nude angels hover to the left of God. The lower-most angel is nude and faces to the right. His body is turned away from the viewer, and twists slightly to the right; his right leg, which is extended backward, crosses behind his left at the knee. He has short, curly hair and holds an open book in his right hand.
Four nude angels hover to the left of God. The lower-most angel is nude and faces to the right. He holds a book showing several separated leaves.
We see the head of Job's wife just below Satan's extended left arm. She faces forward and very slightly to the right; her long hair merges with the surrounding flames.

Satan hovers in flames in the middle. He is nude except for a flame covering his genitals. His arms are raised vertically with the fingers of both hands spread apart. His mouth is open and he may be speaking. His bare feet are prominent.
We see the head of Job just below Satan's extended right arm. He faces forward and slightly to the right. His long hair and beard merge with the surrounding flames.
Satan hovers before flames in the middle with one tongue of fire extending over his right thigh. The faces of Job and his wife appear within the flames.

Five angels hover right of God and Satan. We see only the head and back of the upper-most figure. Like his companions, he may be nude; his hair is short and curly. He faces down and to the left and may be bowing before God.

Five angels hover right of God and Satan. We see only the head, most of the face, and part of the body of the second figure from the top. This figure, which appears to be nude and has fairly long hair, faces down and to the left as if bowing before God.

Five angels hover right of God and Satan. The third figure from the top faces down and to the left, with his head raised and his lower body turned toward the viewer; he may be bowing before God. He is nude and has curly hair of medium length. His left leg is slightly bent at the knee, and his bare feet are prominent. He reaches forward to the left and gestures with both hands toward a scroll. He may have placed the scroll before God's throne.

Five angels hover right of God and Satan. The lowest two in the group are clustered together, with the rear-most figure, a (gowned?) male half covered by his companion. He faces forward and to the left, but his upper body must be twisted slightly to the right, given that his arms are extended horizontally to the right, with the palms raised vertically. His hair is long and perhaps curly; his legs are extended to the right and bent at the knees, and his bare right foot is prominent. He looks toward Satan.

Five angels hover right of God and Satan. The lowest two in the group are clustered together. The front-most figure faces forward and to the left, with his upper body twisted at the waist. He is nude, and his hair is short and curly. His legs are extended to the right and both are slightly bent at the knee. His left arm is bent across his body, and the right arm is bent upward. He holds a scroll in both hands.

desc.objtitle: Job's Sons and Daughters Overwhelmed by Satan, Object 3 (Butlin 551.3)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene shows the destruction of Job's family at the hands of Satan. The background is filled with dark flames and, at the top, bolts of lightning. Below are falling architectural elements, including at least two columns and steps. On and about these steps are, just above the bottom margin, a gowned female lying supine, perhaps dead, with a lyre at her left hand and a tambourine at her feet. In the near foreground on the right is a nude male in an upside-down cruciform posture, with large plates and vessels below him. Another upside-down figure hangs just left of the lower right margin. The other figures in the lower half of the design are, from left to right, a group of three females(?) clearly terrified (we see only their heads and gesturing arms and hands); two females reaching (for succor?) toward the male to the right; a large central nude male (whose posture, reversed, suggests that of Laocoön in the famous classical sculpture) with a child on his left shoulder; and a group of five figures below the central male, all with upraised arms. Above, Satan grins maniacally as he rains fire on his victims from his outstretched hands. He is half-kneeling, legs crossed, on stony blocks; his bat-like wings dominate the top of the design. Radiance and bolts of lightning frame his head with a parodic halo.

component.illusobjdesc: The background is filled with blue and gray flames.
Bolts of lightning flash from behind Satan's head and body. Stormy clouds, or, perhaps, smoke surround him.

Satan, in the top third of the design, half-kneels on a large block, probably of stone. Another such block appears just right of his right foot. These are probably broken pieces of the house of Job's eldest son. They may be falling on the figures below.

Two falling columns, probably made of stone, indicate the destruction of the house of Job's eldest son. The upper-most column has a simple classical capital. The block under the lower column fragment, and just left of the right margin, may also be a broken column.

The figures in the lower margins are displayed on or about a series of (stone?) steps rising from left to right. In the lower right corner is what may be another step, or perhaps stone block, visible just right of the upside-down figure in the foreground.
At least two large plates or platters, one goblet, and a vase or bottle fill the space beneath the outstretched arms of the upside-down figure in the lower right corner.
A tambourine rests beneath the feet of the supine woman just above the bottom margin. A lyre rests under her left hand.

A gowned young woman—a member of Job's family now being destroyed—lies supine just above the lower margin. Her long, curly hair is spread out on the ground; her legs, slightly bent at the knees, are together and her arms are at her sides. A tambourine rests beneath her left(?) foot, and a lyre lies below her left hand. Her head is bent back and her eyes are closed; she may be dead.

A youthful male with curly hair hangs upside down in the lower right corner. His eyes are closed; he appears to be dead. His arms, raised at 135 degrees relative to his body, suggest a cruciform position. His body is twisted, and his legs are bent to the left.

A youthful figure, most likely male, hangs upside down in the lower right corner, just to the right of the more prominent upside-down figure. He appears to be nude and facing up. The back of his head is visible as it rests on the ground. He may be dead.

A group of three females(?) in the middle distance are the left-most figures in the composition. We see only their heads, arms, and upper bodies. The figure farthest to the left is of indeterminate gender and appears to be gowned. She(?) twists her head up, back, and to the right. Her right arm is bent over her head; her left arm is bent, extended across her body, and raised at 135 degrees. Her hair is probably short.

A group of three females(?) in the middle distance are the left-most figures in the composition. We see only their heads, arms, and upper bodies. The figure second from the left faces forward and right with her head up and eyes raised; she is wearing a gown, and has long, curly hair. Her mouth is open, and her facial expression suggests fear. The position of her right shoulder suggests that she is reaching upwards toward the climbing male figure.

A group of three figures in the middle distance are the left-most figures in the composition. The figure third from the left is of indeterminate gender. He(?) faces forward and right with his head up and eyes raised. His hair is curly, and his mouth is open in an expression of pain or terror.

Two young, long-haired, and gowned females are pictured immediately to the left of the central male figure. They both raise their arms at 135 degrees toward the male, who appears to be helping at least the front-most female to rise and climb the steps. The fingers of the woman in the background are spread. The front-most figure in this group faces to the right, with her head bent back. Her right leg is drawn up and bent beneath her as she kneels on a step; her left leg is extended backward and bent at the knee. Her right arm is raised; with her right hand she grasps the arm of the central male, who grasps her arm in turn. A tail of drapery from her gown curls behind her left(?) foot.

Two young, long-haired, and gowned females are pictured immediately to the left of the central male figure. They both raise their arms at 135 degrees toward the male, who appears to be helping at least the front-most female rise and climb the steps. The female figure just to the right of and above the front-most female reaches upward with her palms raised vertically and her fingers spread. She is gowned, and at least one of her legs is bent at the knee as she climbs upward; her (right?) knee and foot are visible behind the central male's left leg. She faces upward and to the right with head bent back and her eyes raised. Her expression suggests pain or terror.

A female figure, with right arm raised at 135 degrees, palm vertical, and fingers clearly visible, appears beneath the central male's left knee. We see her face, raised right arm and hand, and possibly part of her back and upper right leg, the leg perhaps covered with drapery. Her eyes are closed as she faces to the right, and her hair appears to be long.

A group of five figures is pictured below the central male figure. They reach upward, as though seeking aid from the male. The leftmost figure, who appears to be male and nude, is seen from behind with his head turned upward and body slightly twisted. His head is bent back, and his arms are raised with palms vertical and fingers spread.

A group of five figures is pictured below the central male figure. They reach upward, as though seeking aid from the male. The figure second from the left, who appears to be nude and female, is seen from behind, her head turned upward and her body twisted.

A group of five figures is pictured below the central male figure. They reach upward, as though seeking aid from the male. The (male?) figure third from the left is seen from behind with his arms raised vertically to grasp the uppermost step with his right hand and the step immediately below with his left. He has curly hair, and appears to be partly nude, with a gown covering his lower body.

A group of five figures is pictured below the central male figure. They reach upward, as though seeking aid from the male. The (male?) figure second to the left of the upside-down male is seen from behind with his arms raised vertically to grasp the uppermost step.

A group of five figures is pictured below the central male figure. They reach upward, as though seeking aid from the male. The right-most figure in this group appears to be nude and male. We see him from behind; his head is bent back and faces to the left. His arms are raised vertically above his head with both palms out and up. He has curly hair, his mouth is open, and his expression suggests pain, terror, or fear.

A youthful and muscular male dominates the center in the lower half portion. He stands and faces forward, with his left leg bent sharply at the knee to position his foot on a raised step. His right leg is extended to the left. He may be attempting to climb the steps to the right. His upper body and neck are twisted to the left; he may be looking at the females to the left. His posture echoes that of Laocoön, reversed, in the famous classical sculpture group. He is nude except for a bit of drapery that extends along the right side of his chest and covers his genitals. He extends his right arm downward to grasp the upper arm of the female to the left. His left arm is bent upward to hold a child sitting on his left shoulder. The fingers of his left hand are spread apart. His hair is short and curly.

A young (female?) child or infant with curly hair sits on the shoulder of the central male figure. We see her from behind, with her head twisted to the left so that she faces us. Her mouth is slightly open, possibly in an expression of fear. Her extended left arm reaches to the left; she appears to be grasping the hair of the male with her left hand. The child appears to be wearing a gown with drapery.

A nude Satan with bat-like wings dominates the top portion. He squats, crouches, or half-kneels, with legs sharply bent, on some stony blocks, his legs crossed just above the ankles. His arms are extended outward from his body at 45 degrees, with his fingers spread apart, his palms facing down, and flames issuing from his hands and fingertips. His hair is short and curly. He faces forward with eyes closed, or possibly cast sharply downward. His head is twisted down and to the right. Lightning and radiance flash from behind and surrounds his head and body in a manner suggestive of a parodic halo. A slight, and no doubt sardonic, smile indicates his pleasure in destruction.

desc.objtitle: The Messengers Tell Job of His Misfortunes, Object 4 (Butlin 551.4)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A messenger runs, left to right, toward Job and his wife to tell them of the destruction of their family at Satan's hands. He wears a gown, which loops over his left shoulder but exposes his chest and legs below the knees, and strides energetically towards the couple. Job raises his hands as if in prayer; his wife lifts her hands, interdigitated, above her head. A ram grazes far right, below the (stony?) seat or bench on which Job (and his wife?) sit. A tree, perhaps an oak, rises along the right margin and extends its branches and leaves along the top margin of the design. Two stone pillars form the background for Job and his wife; to the left are two grazing sheep and, in the background, a clump of trees and, further back, hills. The sky contains dark clouds, perhaps suggesting a coming storm. Another messenger, wearing breeches and perhaps holding a staff, strides energetically forward and to the left in the middle background. Trees and a Gothic building, perhaps a church, are pictured in the middle distance on the far left. The foreground, raised into a mound, is covered with grass.

component.illusobjdesc: Job's wife, gowned, sits next to her husband. Her legs face to the left, but her upper body and head are twisted toward the viewer; her hair is long and her eyes are raised upward. She raises her upward-bent arms above her head with her palms together and her fingers interlinked, perhaps in prayer. Her mouth is open and may be crying out in grief.

Job sits on the right. He is gowned, with his arms bent upward. His hands are together, his mouth is open, and his head is back so that he looks up. His posture suggests that he may be praying. His long beard and hair cascade over his upper body, and his bare left foot is prominent.

A youthful and muscular male messenger runs in from the left margin and toward Job and his wife. He strides dramatically, legs spread; his right arm reaches back and points horizontally to the left, and his left arm is raised to the right at 135 degrees. The fingers of both hands are slightly spread apart, and the palm of the left hand faces out. His hair stands on end at the back of his head because of his onrushing speed. His mouth is slightly open; he may be speaking as he approaches. His facial features suggest a mixture of grief and fear. His gown covers his body only from the waist to just above his knees, like a skirt, but with a belt or strap looped over his left shoulder. His body faces forward, with his head turned almost completely to the right. His bare feet are prominent.

A second male messenger, who is seen between the legs of the large messenger in the foreground, strides energetically to the left. He has short hair. He wears breeches, a hat, and a shirt of some kind. His body faces to the left but his upper body and head are turned forward to face the viewer. Both arms are bent, his right in front of him to hold the staff, his left behind his back. His legs are bent at the knee, with his left leg bent forward and his right leg bent back.
A Gothic (stone?) building, perhaps a church, appears lower left in the middle distance. It has spires and the arched outlines of at least two doors.
Two sheep graze in the middle distance, half their bodies covered by the stone pillar to the right.
Behind Job and his wife are two stone pillars. The shading between the two hints at a third pillar or a wall.
Job sits on a (stone?) chair. We do not see what his wife sits on; perhaps this is a bench-like seat that can accommodate two.
A ram, with a prominent and looping horn, grazes lower right. We see only the front third of his body.
The foreground rises from lower left to right to form a slight mound on which the principal figures are disposed.
The foreground is grassy.
A large tree, perhaps an oak, grows up the right margin of and spreads its large leaves just below the top margin.
A clump of trees rises between the messenger’s left leg and the sheep. Another hill appears left of the messenger's left leg.
A large hill rises above the clump of trees between the messenger’s left leg and the sheep. Another hill appears left of the messenger’s left leg.
An earthen bank or dirt road descends to the left before the second messenger.
A hill or distant mountain forms the horizon on the left.
Dark clouds fill the sky, suggesting a storm.

desc.objtitle: Satan Going Forth from the Presence of the Lord and Job's Charity, Object 5 (Butlin 551.5)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job and his wife sit side by side on a stone bench in the lower portion of the design. Her right hand is on her breast as she leans toward her husband. Her left hand holds his right upper arm. Job holds a rectangular object, probably half a loaf of bread, in his right hand. With his left hand he gives a similar half-loaf to an old man with a crutch and a dog on a leash. Behind the recipient of Job's charity is a winged angel. Another winged angel hovers on the left. The near foreground is grassy. The middle distance contains grassy hills and the outlines of what are probably bushes or trees. On the left is a structure suggestive of a Druid trilithon, except that it has three rather than two columns. Beside this structure is what appears to be a fragment of another pillar, indicative of ruins. The horizon is defined by distant mountains with clouds above. The upper portion portrays several dramatic figures, particularly Satan. He is nude. Flames ascend to the right from behind Satan's extended legs and right hand. The flames below his left arm and hand point downward. He holds a vial in his right hand from which a liquid(?), perhaps indicative of pestilence, descends on Job. On the left, nine(?) figures hover among flames, probably angels although without wings. On the right nine(?) more angels are similarly arranged in the ascending flames. Smoke, or perhaps clouds, encircle Satan and these angelic figures. In the center of this oval composition, God sits on a stone throne, raised on a plinth. He faces forward, with his head turned to the right and slightly down, holding a book in his right hand and a scroll in his left. An oval of radiance surrounds his head and upper body.

component.illusobjdesc: Job sits at the center in the lower half of the design. He is gowned, but his bare right foot extends beyond the hem of his garment. His left leg may be crossed behind his right at the ankles. He is bearded and his hair is long. His right arm is bent, and his right hand, resting on his lap, holds half a loaf of bread; his left arm is extended horizontally and bent slightly upward. He holds another half-loaf in his left hand, which he gives to an old man on crutches.
Job holds two half-loaves of bread; one rests in his lap, held by his right hand, the other is held in his left hand.

Job's wife sits beside him. She is gowned and has long hair. Her bare left foot is visible beneath the hem of her garment. She leans toward her husband, with her left hand, fingers spread, holding his upper left arm. Her right arm is bent, with her right hand resting on her breast.

A gowned and winged angel hovers near the lower left margin. His arms are bent upward, and his hands, although together at the wrists, are separated from one another, palms vertical, to form a V. His head and short, curly hair are encircled by a halo of radiant light. His bare right foot is visible.

A gowned and winged angel hovers near the lower right margin, facing left. His left arm is bent upward and his palms are together in a posture suggestive of prayer. His head and short, curly hair are encircled by a halo of radiant light. His bare left foot is visible.

An old man leaning on a crutch stands facing to the left with his eyes cast down or closed. He may be blind. His left leg is bent behind his right. His hair, beard, and gown are long; his bare left foot is prominent. His left arm is bent at the elbow and extended to receive an object (probably a small loaf of bread) from Job in the slightly spread fingers of his left hand. A thin leash extends from the dog's neck toward the old man on the right. He may be a beggar.
A small dog, head down and perhaps sniffing the ground, appears just to the right of Job. A thin leash extends from the dog's neck toward the old man on the right.
Job and his wife sit on a bench or seat of some sort, probably made of stone.
Grass occupies the foreground. Behind the figures rise grass-covered hills, and, right and left, the outlines of what are probably bushes or trees.
Hills and mountains dominate the landscape background behind Job and his wife.

Left of Job's wife, a structure that resembles a stone trilithon (except that it has three columns rather than the usual two) appears in the middle distance. To the left of this structure is the fragment of what may be an additional pillar. The scene is suggestive of ruins.

God sits, enthroned, in the top center of the design. He is old and bearded, has long hair, and wears a gown. His bare feet are both prominent, but particularly the right foot. He reaches down to hold a book (right hand) and a scroll (left hand). His left leg is slightly bent at the knee but extends downward; his right leg is bent sharply at the knee and drawn up toward his torso. He faces forward but looks down and to the right. An aura of radiance forms a backdrop for his head and upper body.
God holds a book in his right hand.
God holds a scroll in his left hand.
God sits, enthroned, on a chair or seat of some sort. Its rounded arms can be seen left and right of his forearms.
God's throne and both his feet rest on a three-step plinth, probably made of stone.

Satan, a youthful male, hovers (or flies rapidly) beneath God. He is nude. His hair is short and curly. The position of his limbs suggests dramatic movement, perhaps descending or curving from right to left. He faces forward, with his head twisted upward toward God. His left leg is extended up and to the right; his right leg is bent sharply at the knee and drawn up toward his upper right thigh. His left arm, bent slightly at the elbow, is extended over his head and to the left (but raised vertically relative to his body); his right arm is extended downward but at a right angle relative to his torso. The palm of his left hand faces down. The fingers of his left hand are spread slightly apart. He holds a vial in his right hand from which a liquid descends. Both feet are prominent.
Satan holds a vial in his right hand. A liquid descends from it toward Job. This may represent the diseases that will plague Job.

Satan is surrounded by flames that my be issuing from just behind the vial in his right hand. Other flames back the angels surrounding God, right and left. Behind the flame are bands of clouds or possibly smoke.
Nine(?) figures, probably male angels, hover left of God. The angel at top left faces forward and to the right, with his left arm bent at 45 degrees. He is gowned and has short, curly hair.

Nine(?) figures, probably male angels, hover left of God. Only the heads and upper bodies of the three angels at the top right of this group are visible. They face forward and to the right, and may have long hair.

Nine(?) figures, probably male angels, hover left of God. The angel second from the top on the left side of the group faces downward and to the right. Only his(?) head and upper body are visible; he has long hair.

Nine(?) figures, probably male angels, hover left of God. Only the heads and upper bodies of the angels fourth and fifth from the top on the right side are visible. They face downward and to the right, and have short, curly hair. The left arm of the angel on the left is bent upward across his chest. His mouth may be open. Both may be gowned.

Nine(?) figures, probably male angels, hover left of God. The entire bodies of the two lowermost angels are visible. The angel on the left is a gowned male with short, curly hair. He faces forward and left but leans to the right and looks towards God. His arms are bent upward to the left, with hands raised, palms out, and fingers spread. His bare feet are prominent.

Nine(?) figures, probably male angels, hover left of God. We see the lowest figure in the group from behind, with his body and face turned to the right. He is nude, and his buttocks and bare feet are prominent. His hair is long and his right arm is bent forward, with the palm facing out and fingers spread. His right leg is extended and his left bent at the knee.
Nine(?) figures, probably male angels, hover right of God. We see only the rough outlines of the top four angels. They face forward and lean to the left, towards God. They may have long hair.

Nine(?) figures, probably male angels, hover right of God. Only the heads and shoulders of the angels fourth and fifth from the bottom of the group are visible. The angel on the left has curly, perhaps short hair. He(?) faces forward and to the left; his eyes look towards God. The angel at right has long hair. Both are gowned.

Nine(?) figures, probably male angels, hover right of God. Only the head and upper body of the angel third from the bottom are visible. He appears to be gowned, and has short, curly hair. He faces forward but leans and bends his head to the left.

Nine(?) figures, probably male angels, hover right of God. The figure second from the bottom faces forward and to the right, but his upper body and head are twisted to the left and downward. His right leg is extended downward. He has fairly long hair.

desc.objtitle: Satan Smiting Job with Boils, Object 6 (Butlin 551.6)
desc.related: The very light sketch, preparatory for the engravings, of the lowered head and back of a figure seen in profile, above and right of center in Object 4 of the sketchbook, may be related to Job’s wife, kneeling at Job’s feet in Object 6 in the Linnell series of water colors, or to one of Job’s friends in Object 8 in the Linnell series of water colors.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job, in his misery, lies upon a bed of straw, his head bent back and his arms at his side, with both palms raised vertically and the fingers slightly spread. He rests his feet against his wife, who kneels hunched over at his feet, her head down and in her hands in grief and despair. She is gowned; Job's loins are covered with a rough (burlap?) cloth. A triumphant Satan stands above Job, his feet resting on Job's abdomen and just below his left kneecap. Satan is nude, but we can clearly see scales on his upper legs, upper body, over his genital area, and over his shoulders. His arms are raised horizontally; four arrows descend in front of his right hand. He holds a vial in his left hand from which spill liquid or flames. The background is dominated by billowing clouds (of smoke?) and a sun that is rising or (more probably) setting over the ocean on the far left. Ruined walls or buildings, a broken cromlech or portal, and broken columns appear in the folds of the hills in the middle distance and background. A mountain rises in the horizon, its peak obscured by Satan's body. Grass appears in the foreground, just above the lower margin.

component.illusobjdesc: Job lies supine on a bed of straw. His body seems rigid, with his head bent back in an expression of extreme pain. His hair and beard are long. His arms are at his side, with both palms raised vertically and the fingers slightly spread. He is nude except for a rough (burlap?) cloth that covers his loins. His prominent bare feet rest on the legs of his kneeling wife.
Job lies on a bed or mound of straw.

Job's wife kneels at her husband's feet, which touch her thighs. She is gowned; her hair his long. She is bent over in a contracted posture, with her head down and her face covered by her upraised hands. We see her bare right foot. Her posture suggests despair.

A muscular Satan triumphs over Job, his feet resting on Job's lower legs and abdomen. He faces forward, looking down toward Job, with legs spread apart and arms raised horizontally. His mouth is open, with the suggestion of a sardonic smile; his hair is short and curly. His head and neck are twisted downward and to the right; his torso leans to the right. He is nude, but scales are clearly pictured on his upper thighs, upper body, genital area, and over his shoulders. Four arrows descend in front of his right hand, palm out. He holds a vial in his left hand from which spill liquid or flames.
Four arrows descend in front of Satan's raised right hand. They may emblemize the disease that plagues Job.
Satan holds in his left hand a vial from which spill liquid or flames. These may emblemize the diseases that plague Job.
Grass appears in the lower margin. The mottled texture of the hills in the middle distance also suggest vegetation of some sort.
Low hills dominate the middle distance. A mountain rises on the horizon, its peak obscured by Satan's body.
A sun rises (or more probably sets) above the ocean. Beams of light and radiance surround the sun, though overcast with clouds or smoke.
Billowing clouds (of smoke?) fill the sky on both sides of Satan.
A ruined wall, perhaps of a building, appears behind Job's head. Just to the left, and farther in the distance, is another structure, probably also a ruin. Both are probably made of stone.

The trilithon in the middle distance has an arch, with its right corner damaged. There are four(?) additional ruined posts or pillars in the middle distance just left of Satan's lower right leg. Even farther in the background to the left of Satan, there are three(?) ruined posts with a fourth(?) pillar toppled (to the left of the three posts) over the ground. All are probably stone.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job sits on the right in his misery, nude except for a rough (burlap?) cloth over his lap. He appears to be resting uncomfortably on a bed of straw piled into a mound (or covering a mound of earth). The rough texture of his flesh suggests the sore boils that afflict him, and his expression suggests despair and pain. His head is twisted to the right, and his eyes look upward (for solace?). His arms are bent at his side, with the fingers of his left hand spread slightly apart. His wife stands behind him, her arms sharply bent upward and her palms out (fingers spread) in an expression of despair and grief. Her head is twisted to the left and her mouth slightly parted. Job's three friends enter in a rush, arms and hands raised, on the left. Eliphaz the Temanite is the figure leading the group; his identity is made clear in Object 9. If the friends enter in the same order as they are introduced in Job 2:11, then the next figure to the left is Bildad the Shuhite and farthest to the left is Zophar the Naamathite. Various ruined walls, buildings, and pillars adorn the hills in the middle distance. Other walls or pillars anchor the far right margin. The near foreground contains grass. The mottled texture of the hills in the middle distance suggests more vegetation. A burst of light (from a setting sun?) radiates above the distant mountains.

component.illusobjdesc: Job sits on the right in his misery, nude except for a rough (burlap?) cloth over his lap. He leans back against his wife. He appears to be resting uncomfortably on a bed of straw on top of a mound (of earth?). The rough texture of Job’s flesh, as indicated by gray splotches distinct from the foxing that mars much of the design, suggests the sore boils that afflict him. His expression suggests despair and pain. His arms are bent at his side, with the fingers of his left hand spread slightly apart. His right hand rests on a small mound of straw or a piece of sackcloth with a herringbone pattern, similar to his loincloth. His hair and beard are long; his bare feet are prominent.

Job lies on a bed of straw, apparently piled into a mound or spread over a mound of earth. His right hand rests on a small mound of straw or a piece of sackcloth with a herringbone pattern, similar to his loincloth.

Job’s wife kneels behind him with her left leg bent at the knee and her left foot visible. Her arms are bent sharply upward at the elbows, palms out (and slightly up) and fingers spread, in an expression of grief and despair. She is gowned, has long hair, and faces forward, with her head twisted to the left and down. She looks down upon Job. Her mouth is slightly open; she may be speaking or crying out in lamentation. Her face is deeply lined, as though worn with worry.

Job's three friends enter in a rush, arms and hands raised, on the left. Eliphaz the Temanite is the figure leading the group; his identity is made clear in Object 9. His hair is fairly long, but not as long as his flowing beard. He is gowned and faces right; both bare feet and the agitated hem of his garment are prominent. The fingers of both raised hands (palms up or out) are spread apart. His visage suggests grief and surprise.

Job's three friends enter in a rush, arms and hands raised, on the left. If the friends enter in the same order as they are introduced in Job 2:11, then the middle figure is Bildad the Shuhite. His hair and beard are curly. He is gowned and faces right; his bare right foot is pictured. The fingers of both raised hands (palms up or out) are spread apart. His head is bent back so that his head faces up.

Job's three friends enter in a rush, arms and hands raised, on the left. If the friends enter in the same order as they are introduced in Job 2:11, then the last figure on the left is Zophar the Naamathite. We see only his arms, head, and upper body. His hair would appear to be long. He is gowned and faces right and slightly forward. The fingers of both raised hands (palms up) are spread apart.
Job's wife casts a shadow on the wall behind her.
Walls and/or pillars, perhaps of a (ruined?) building, rise along the right margin. There are also two steps, lower right. All these structures would appear to be made of stone.
A low (stone?) wall forms the backdrop for Job's right lower arm and hand.
Several ruined structures rise among the hills in the middle distance. These include walls (of buildings?) and broken pillars. All are probably made of stone.
Grass adorns the foreground.

The middle distance is dominated by low hills, with larger mountains on the horizon. Above these is a wide beam of light; a radiant glow emanates from behind the mountain, suggesting a rising—or more probably setting—sun.

desc.related: The very light sketch, preparatory for the engravings, of the lowered head and back of a figure seen in profile, above and right of center in Object 4 of the sketchbook, may be related to one of Job’s friends in Object 8 in the Linnell series of water colors or to Job’s wife, kneeling at Job’s feet, in Object 6 in the Linnell series of water colors.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job, in his agony and despair, sits on a bed of straw. He is nude except for a rough (burlap?) cloth over his lap. He faces forward, with knees drawn up and both feet prominent. His arms are raised vertically, with the palms of his raised hands up and out. His hair is probably long; tears cascade down his cheeks and long beard. The rough texture of his flesh suggests the boils that afflict him. To the left is Job's wife, kneeling and hunched over in grief and despair. Her contracted body, facing right, is gowned; her long hair cascades over her face. On the right, also kneeling and hunched over with faces obscured, are Job's three friends. If our identifications in Object 7 are correct, then these are (from left to right) Eliphaz (or possibly Zophar), Bildad, and Zophar (or possibly Eliphaz). All are gowned. Grass adorns the foreground. An archway, with heavy post and lintel, stands in the middle distance on the right. A low (grassy?) hill extends through the entire middle distance. Behind are a range of mountains and a stormy sky filled with dark clouds and possibly smoke.

component.illusobjdesc: Job, in his agony and despair, sits on a bed of straw. He is nude except for a rough (burlap?) cloth over his lap. He faces forward, with knees drawn up and both feet prominent. His arms are raised vertically, with the palms of his raised hands up and out. His hair is probably long; tears cascade down his cheeks and long beard. His mouth is open; he may be speaking or crying out in pain. The rough texture of his flesh suggests the boils that afflict him.
Job sits on a bed of straw piled into a mound.

Job's wife kneels to the left of her husband. She is hunched over in a posture expressive of grief and despair. Her contracted body, facing right, is gowned; her long hair cascades over her face. Her feet are prominent.

Job's three friends kneel, facing left, in severely contracted postures expressive of grief or despair. Their faces are hidden, and all three figures wear gowns. Given their identifications we have proposed in Object 7, the front-most figure is either Eliphaz (although his hair is much longer here than in Object 7) or Zophar. His left arm is bent sharply at the elbow as he reaches forward with his left hand (fingers spread) over his cascading hair.

Job's three friends kneel, facing left, in severely contracted postures expressive of grief or despair. Their faces are hidden, and all three figures wear gowns. Given their identifications we have proposed in Object 7 the middle figure is probably Bildad (note the curly hair).

Job's three friends kneel, facing left, in severely contracted postures expressive of grief or despair. Their faces are hidden, and all three figures wear gowns. Given their identifications we have proposed in Object 7, the last figure in the group, closest to Job, is probably Zophar, although he might be Eliphaz. We see only the top of his head, covered with (long?) hair. A pair of clasped hands probably belongs to this last figure in the group.
Grass adorns the foreground beneath Job, his wife, and his friends.
A low (grassy?) hill fills the middle distance behind the figures.
Dark mountains define the horizon. The mountain peak on the left seems oddly tilted to the left.
Dark clouds fill the sky. The most prominent billow upward, and thus these may be clouds of smoke from the continued destruction of Job's world.
An archway, with heavy stone post and lintel, dominates the middle distance behind Job's friends.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Eliphaz kneels, lower right, with left arm raised as he tells his vision of God to Job and his wife. Job's two other friends, Bildad and Zophar, knee near the right margin. Job, again on his bed of straw, looks upward to the vision of God, who stands above, with radiance and beams of light around him. Eliphaz, in his vision above, is in bed, his hand gesture and hair standing on end indicating his fear of God. The vision in the sky is surrounded by dark cloud bands. Below, before a background of dark sky, we also find Job's wife, seated on the far left and with her face turned upward. Grass grows in the foreground.

component.illusobjdesc: Job sits or reclines on his bed of straw. His knees, drawn up, are covered by a rough (burlap?) cloth; his left foot pokes out from below this garment. His upper body may be undraped or covered with a gown or shirt—note the line at his left wrist indicating a cuff. He props up his body with his left arm, bent at the elbow; his right arm is bent across his chest, with the fingers of his right hand spread apart. His body faces forward, but his head is twisted up to look at the vision of God in the sky. His hair and beard are long.
Job reclines on a bed or low mound of straw.

Job's wife sits or kneels in the lower left corner. She faces forward, but twists her head upward to look at the vision of God above. She is gowned, with her right arm by her side and her right hand on the ground. Her left arm is bent at the elbow, with her right hand across her breast.

Eliphaz kneels lower right, his left arm and hand (palm up) raised toward his vision of God he is describing to Job. He is gowned and faces left; his beard and hair are long. His right arm extends toward his knees, upon which his right hand rests. His mouth is open; he may be speaking or praying.

Two of Job's friends kneel or sit near the lower right margin. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, the friend farthest to the right is Bildad (note the curly hair and beard). He is gowned and faces left, with his head twisted up and to the left. His hands are clasped together under his chin in an attitude of prayer. His mouth may be slightly open.

Two of Job's friends kneel or sit near the lower right margin. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, the third figure from the front is probably Zophar. He is probably kneeling, like his companion, but we can see only his upturned face.

In Eliphaz's vision, pictured in the sky, God stands as an ancient patriarch with long hair and beard. He is gowned and faces right, his right arm apparently bent at the elbow and extended over his chest beneath his garment. He appears to be looking directly at Eliphaz to the right. His body is surrounded by radiance and beams of light.

In Eliphaz's vision, pictured in the sky, the visionary himself appears. He reclines in a bed, his body propped up against a pillow. He faces left and has a long beard. His spiky hair stands on end, indicating fright at the vision of God before him. His left arm is bent at the elbow, with the palm of his left hand (fingers slightly spread) facing toward God. Eliphaz wears a gown (nightgown?), or at least a shirt. His eyes are wide open as he beholds his vision of God.
In his vision, Eliphaz lies in bed, a sheet covering his body up to the chest. There would appear to be a pillow behind his head.
Beams of light and radiance extend outward from God.
Eliphaz's vision in the sky is framed by dark cloud bands.
The foreground appears to be barren and possibly sandy.
There is a mountain in the far distance between Job and his wife. The lightly-colored form in the background right of Job may be another mountain or hill.
The background, in the lower portion of the design, contains a dark sky. This may be a night (or twilight?) scene.

desc.objtitle: Job Rebuked by His Friends, Object 10 (Butlin 551.10)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job kneels on his bed of straw, center left, his mouth slightly open and tears running down his cheeks and long beard. He is nude above the waist; a piece of rough (burlap?) cloth covers his loins and legs. His hands are down by his thighs, palms out. The mottled textures on his upper body, lower arms, and palms indicate the boils that plague him. His eyes are turned upward, as though he is beseeching his God. His posture, visage, and gestures suggest pain and despair. Job's wife sits far left, her head twisted toward her husband. Her hair is long; her face now looks a good deal older than in earlier scenes. Both feet extend from under the hem of her gown. Her knees are drawn up sharply toward her chest, with both arms wrapped around them. Her hands are open, fingers spread, in a gesture that suggests she is questioning Job and his fate. Job's three friends (probably Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar, front to back) sit, squat, or stand on the right. They are gowned and point accusatory arms, hands, and fingers at Job. The middle distance is filled with a low hill, perhaps covered with vegetation. A bit of vegetation, probably grass, adorns the foreground. A large pillar, or section of a wall, anchors the left margin. The horizon is defined by dark mountains; above, the sky is stormy, with dark clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: Job kneels, facing forward, on his bed of straw, center left, his mouth slightly open and tears running down his cheeks and long beard. He is nude above the waist; a piece of rough (burlap?) cloth covers his loins and legs. His hair is long and his hands are down by his thighs, palms out. The mottled textures on his upper body, lower arms, and palms indicate the boils that plague him. His eyes are turned upwards, as though he is beseeching his God. His posture, visage, and gestures suggest pain and despair.

Job's wife sits far left, her head twisted toward her husband. Her mouth is open, as though she is speaking to Job. Her hair is long; both feet extend from under the hem of her gown. Her knees are drawn up sharply toward her chest, with both arms wrapped around them. Her hands are open, fingers spread, in a gesture that suggests she, in her despair, is pointing toward and questioning Job and their shared fate.

Job's three friends appear in the right margin. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, the front-most figure is probably Eliphaz. He sits with his right knee on the ground and his left knee drawn up toward his torso. He is old, bearded, and gowned, with long hair. His left foot extends from under the hem of his garment. His body faces forward, turned somewhat to the left, as looks toward Job and raises both arms horizontally and points, with an accusatory gesture, toward Job. His mouth is open; he may be speaking. His extended fingers are spread apart, particularly on his left hand.

Job's three friends appear in the right margin. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, the second figure from the front is very probably Bildad. He is gowned, with short curly hair and beard. He would appear to be squatting on the ground; we can see his right knee and right foot. His body faces to the left, with his head turned towards Job. He raises both arms horizontally and points, with an accusatory gesture, toward Job. His extended fingers are spread apart, particularly on his left hand.

Job's three friends appear in the right margin. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, the third and last figure from the front is probably Zophar. He is gowned, with long hair and beard, and his right foot extends from the hem of his gown. He is probably standing, given his height relative to his companions. His body probably faces to the left, with his head turned toward us, but he would appear to be looking at Job. He raises both arms horizontally and points, with an accusatory gesture, toward Job. His extended fingers are spread apart.
Job's bed or mound of straw appears just to the right of his left arm, beneath his knees, and apparently extends behind Job and his accusatory friends.
Grass appears in the foreground.
The hills in the middle distance appear to be grassy.
A wall or pillar of stone rises upper left.
The landscape background for the figures is composed of hills in the middle distance and a range of mountains on the horizon.
A dark storm cloud in the upper left corner hovers in the sky. The surrounding clouds are dark and stormy as well.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Now at his lowest point, physically and spiritually, Job lies supine on a bed or bier and confronts the devil/god of his false vision. Entwined with a serpent and cloven-footed, that god points up and to the left with his right hand toward the decalogue; with his left hand, he points downward to hell. Lightning and dark clouds fill the distant sky. Below, two devils reach upward toward Job, apparently in an attempt to drag him to the fires of hell below. A third devil with scaly skin holds a chain to bind Job's body and mind.

component.illusobjdesc: Job lies supine on a bed or bier. His legs are together; a rough cloth (burlap?) covers his loins. He is bearded and has long hair; his arms are bent at the elbow, with his lower arms raised vertically, his hands raised horizontally, and his fingers slightly spread. His body faces upward, but his head is turned towards us as he looks down at the demon below him. His open mouth—indeed, his whole visage—expresses terror. He may be speaking or crying out in fear.

Job's false vision of god hovers horizontally above the afflicted man. He is aged and gowned, with long, twisted, and spiky hair (rather flame-like) and a long beard. Only his left foot is visible; it is a cloven hoof. His right arm is raised at 45 degrees as he points to the decalogue in the background. His left arm, raised at 135 degrees relative to his body, points downward to hell. He is intertwined with a serpent and his lips are parted slightly; he may be speaking.
Job's false god is intertwined with a serpent. The serpent is scaly and has fangs.

A nude devil or demon reaches upward with his right arm and grasps Job's lower left leg. We can also see the fingers of his left hand grasp Job's lower right leg. The demon's flesh is marked with stripe-like lines. He faces upwards.

A nude devil or demon reaches upward with his left arm and grasps Job's upper left leg. We can also see the fingers of his right hand grabbing Job's right hip. The demon's body appears smooth, except for the scales on his face, arm and shoulder. He has short curly hair. He faces upward with his mouth open as if speaking.

A devil or demon appears below Job's upper body. Scales cover his neck, face, arms, and the back of his right hand. He faces upward, with mouth open and teeth visible. His hair is short and spiky. He holds, in both upraised hands, a heavy chain. The claw-like fingers of his right hand are slightly spread apart.
The devil or demon lower right holds a chain.
The devil/god points toward the stony tablets of the decalogue. Hebrew letters from the Ten Commandments appear on both tablets.
Both stone tablets bear faint Hebrew inscriptions from the Ten Commandments that are only partly legible; see the textual transcription.
Dark, stormy clouds and bolts of lightening fill the sky above Job's devil/god. A few cloud outlines also appear below the devil/god.
Flames surround Job's bed. Flames appear above Job's legs and along the lower margin of the design. In at least the latter location, they represent the dark fires of hell.
Job lies on a mat of roughly woven (burlap? straw?) fibers which in turn lies on a bed or bier of wood or, more probably, stone.

lg.l: ךAmong the slight indications of Hebrew letters on both stone tablets, only a single letter on the left tablet is legible. This is probably a fragmentary copy of the second letter from the right in the word "ב ת נ" in the Butts water color, Object 11. In the Butts water color, the full text of this line, reading from right to left, may be "God giveth" from Exodus chapter 20, verse 12: "Honour thy father and thy mother; that thy days may be long upon the land which the Lord thy God giveth thee."

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job's young friend, Elihu, enters from the left, right arm extended forward and left arm bent upward at the elbow, his left index finger pointing heavenward. The first figure to the right of Elihu is Job's wife, her legs drawn up and her head bowed in abject despair. Job sits in the middle of the design, his knees drawn up and his arms crossed over his chest. He stares abstractly toward Elihu with unseeing eyes. Job's three friends sit on the right; these are Zophar, Bildad, and Eliphaz (left to right, given our identifications of the friends in Object 7). The middle-distance is filled with low hills, a ruined building, and a large column, or post and lintel, on the far right. Stars shine in the night sky above a distant mountain. Green washes indicate grass on the ground.

component.illusobjdesc: Job's young friend, Elihu, enters from the left, right arm extended forward and left arm bent upward at the elbow, his left index finger pointing heavenward. He strides to the right, with his face in profile to the right, but with his body twisted at the waist so that we see his back. The fingers of his right hand are spread apart slightly. His hair is long and his lips are slightly parted, as though he is speaking. He wears tights that end at his wrists and at the midline of his calves; his right leg is extended behind him, and his feet are bare with his right foot on tiptoe.

The second figure from the left is Job's wife, her legs drawn up and her head bowed in abject despair. Her hands, clasped together possibly in prayer, rest between her prominent knees. Her long hair covers her face. She is gowned, with her prominent and bare left foot extending from beneath the hem of her garment.

Job sits on his mound of straw in the middle. His legs are drawn up, with both knees and feet prominent. His rough cloth lies across his lap. The mottled texture on his upper body, lower arms, and legs indicate the boils that plague him. He stares, blankly and with evident despair, in the general direction of Elihu on the left. His arms are folded over his chest; a few fingers on both hands are spread apart. His hair and beard are long.

Job's three kneeling friends sit on the right; these are Zophar, Bildad, and Eliphaz (left to right, given our identifications of the friends in Object 7). Zophar (the left-most figure) faces forward, with his body partly facing to the left and his eyes down. He is gowned and has long hair and a beard. He looks older than Bildad, but not as old as Eliphaz.

Job's three kneeling friends sit on the right; these are Zophar, Bildad, and Eliphaz (left to right, given our identifications of the friends in Object 7). Bildad (the middle figure) faces forward, with his body partly facing to the left. He is gowned and has curly hair and a beard.

Job's three friends kneel on the right; these are Zophar, Bildad, and Eliphaz (left to right, given our identifications of the friends in Object 7). Eliphaz (the left-most figure) faces to the left, his visage in profile. He is gowned and has long hair and an exceptionally long beard. His extended left arm rests on his lap and left thigh, with the fingers of his left hand (resting on his left knee) spread apart in an unusual gesture with two fingers curled.
Green washes indicate grass in the foreground beneath the figures.
The hills in the middle distance appear to be grassy.
The middle distance is dominated by hills, rising toward a mountain range and peak on the distant horizon.
Thirteen stars illuminate the night sky.
A ruined structure, probably a stone building or wall, appears the middle distance just to the left of Job.
A stone post topped by a lintel rises above Job's three friends on the right. An additional stone block rests on top of the lintel. This structure may be a doorway.
Job sits on his mound-like bed of straw.

desc.objtitle: The Lord Answering Job out of the Whirlwind, Object 13 (Butlin 551.13)

illustration.illusobjdesc: God hovers, arms outstretched, in a whirlwind. Below are Job and his wife (left), both with hands raised in prayer. Job's three friends bow down as though humbled and frightened by God's sublime energies; only Job and his wife gaze upward toward God. Given our identifications of the three friends in Object 7, these are (from front to back) Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. Grass appears in the foreground below the figures. A colonnade or building composed of columns and a long lintel in the middle distance extends left and right of Job and his wife. Behind the structure are hills, with indications of vegetation, and steep mountains in the distance.

component.illusobjdesc: God appears in a whirlwind. Dark and stormy clouds frame the whirlwind on the right and left.

God hovers in a whirlwind. He is ancient and gowned, with extremely long beard and spiky hair. He faces forward and to the left, arms outstretched horizontally. He looks slightly down towards Job and his wife. Both hands, with fingers slightly spread and palms down, are prominent. He may be blessing Job with his right hand and pointing to the right with the index finger of his left hand.

Job kneels on the left, with only the rough cloth covering his lap. He is old and bearded, and has long hair. He faces to the right and up, gazing upon the vision of God in a whirlwind. He appears to be surprised by the vision. His arms are bent upward, with his hands clasped together in prayer.

Job's wife kneels behind and to the right of her husband. Like him, her arms are bent upward with her hands together in prayer. Her body faces right, with her head turned partly forward and upward; she is probably looking at God above. She is gowned; her hair would appear to be long.

Job's three friends bow down as though humbled and frightened by God in the whirlwind above them. Given our identifications of the three friends in Object 7, the front-most figure is probably Eliphaz. He is kneeling with his body bent forward in a severely contracted posture. He is gowned and his hair would appear to be long. His arms are bent upward, cradling his head, and the fingers of his left hand are spread apart. His body faces to the left, with his head down.

Job's three friends bow down as though humbled and frightened by God in the whirlwind above them. Given our identifications of the three friends in Object 7, the middle figure is probably Bildad. He is probably kneeling, with his body bent forward in a severely contracted posture. He is gowned and his hair is short and curly (his identifying feature in several plates). His body faces to the left, with his head down; we see only his back and the top of his head.

Job's three friends bow down as though humbled and frightened by God in the whirlwind above them. Given our identifications of the three friends in Object 7, the third figure from the front is probably Zophar. Like his companions, he is probably kneeling, with his body bent forward in a severely contracted posture. His body must be facing to the left, with his head down, but we see only the top and left side of head. His hair may be curly.
Between the mountains and the long lintel, there are steep hills that appear to be covered in vegetation, possibly trees(?); this vegetation continues beneath God and behind Job’s friends.
Green washes indicate grass in the foreground below the figures.
A colonnade or building composed of columns and a long lintel in the middle distance extends left and right of Job and his wife.
Mountains rise in the far background to the left of God.

desc.objtitle: When the Morning Stars Sang Together, Object 14 (Butlin 551.14)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The complex design is divided by cloud bands into three sections. In the top section are stars and four youthful male angels. All are winged and partly nude, with indications of knee-length gowns or drapery; their arms overlap at 135 degree angles. Inscriptions in the engraved version of this design indicate that these figures are probably personifications of stars. The middle section is anchored by the ancient figure of God kneeling in the center of the design. His arms are outstretched horizontally. Beneath God's right arm is a youthful male riding (or possibly hovering above) one or more of the four horses beneath him.
