The halo or sun disc and the surrounding radiance suggest that he is a sun god, perhaps Apollo. Beneath God's left arm is a winged female holding the reins of two serpents. The crescent moon above her head identifies her as a moon goddess, probably Diana or Hecate. Job and his wife sit or kneel in the lowest section of the design. On the right are Job's three friends. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, these are, from right to left, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. Green washes indicate grass in the foreground.

component.illusobjdesc: The four angels stand on a horizontal band of clouds that extends behind God's extended arms.

A prominent cloud band separates God (center of the design) from the human figures of Job, his wife and three friends, seated below. The clouds descend toward the ground in the right and left margins to form an arch-like form.
Green washes indicate grass in the foreground.
There are 17 stars in the night(?) sky. Four of these stars are directly above the angel's heads, three are between each angel at knee-level, and the rest of the stars surround the angels.

In the top section are stars and four youthful male angels. All are winged and partly nude, with indications of gowns or drapery; the angels appear to have drapery from waist to knee, but are otherwise nude. All but the leftmost angel are covered from shoulder to knee by gowns that are split open in the middle to expose their upper thighs. The angels' arms overlap at 135 degrees. Their hands are raised, with palms turned upward. The fingers of all four angels are at least slightly spread. They face forward; the two angels on the left stride or walk with their right legs in front, and the two on the right with left legs in front. They all appear to be on their tiptoes. Their hair is somewhat long. Inscriptions in the engraved version of this design indicate that these figures are probably personifications of stars. The open mouths of the angels far left and second from the right indicate that they are singing.

God—ancient, gowned, and bearded with long flowing hair—anchors the center of the composition. He sits, squats, or kneels on a cloud band, with his right leg pulled up toward his body (as a result, his right knee and foot are prominent). He faces forward, with arms outstretched horizontally and palms down. A halo appears behind his head. The flowing hem of his garment is prominent.

A youthful and nude male with arms raised horizontally, palms out, appears below God's right arm. He may be pushing against the clouds he touches with both hands. He faces to the left, with his torso bent forward. A halo, or perhaps the disc of the sun with beams of radiance, appears behind his head. He would seem to be hovering over, or possibly riding on, the backs of the four horses beneath him. Lines extending above both of his shoulders suggest wings. His hair is short and curly. Given all these attributes and emblematic associations, this is very probably a sun god, perhaps Apollo.
A youthful and nude male, perhaps Apollo, appears below God's right arm. A halo, or perhaps the disc of the sun with beams of radiance, appears behind his head.

Four horses, charging to the left in serried rank, appear beneath the youthful figure under God's right arm. Their manes appear to be flame-like. The front-most horse's leg is raised in a prideful manner, and the lines parallel to its legs indicate that the legs of the other three horses share a similar posture.

A winged and gowned female appears below God's left arm. She faces forward and to the right, with her arms extended horizontally before her. The palms of her raised hands face down. Her hair may be fairly short and curly, though her right wing obscures the true length of her hair. She holds the reins of two serpents in her hands. The serpents (below her) and the crescent moon above her head identify this figure as a moon goddess, perhaps Diana or Hecate (the latter more frequently associated with serpents).
The female figure below God's left arm holds the reins of two serpents in each hand.

The female figure below God's left arm holds the reins of two serpents with scales and crests. They face to the right, with mouths open and protruding tongues. The foremost serpent's body loops once below the female figure.
There is a crescent moon affixed to the head of the female figure below God's left arm. This moon, as well as the darkness behind her, may indicate that it is night.

Job's wife sits or kneels lower left. She is gowned, with long hair, and faces forward and to the right with her head and eyes turned upward and her mouth open. Her arms are bent at the elbows and her hands are together in prayer.

Job sits on the ground, the second figure from the left. His rough cloth extends over his lower body; his upper body is undraped. His left knee is drawn up toward his torso, with his left foot visible beneath the cloth. He faces forward, with eyes turned upward and head bent back. Both arms are crossed over his chest with his right wrist under his left palm; both palms are facing his chest. He is, as usual, old and bearded with long hair.

Job's three friends sit or kneel lower right. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, these are, from right to left, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. Eliphaz is old and bearded with long hair. He wears a gown, and would appear to be kneeling. He faces up and to the left, with his eyes raised and his head bent back. His left arm is bent at the elbow, with his left hand raised, palm out, as if in prayer or supplication. His right knee is drawn up to his chest, making his right foot prominent. His mouth is open.

Job's three friends sit or kneel lower right. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, these are, from right to left, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. Bildad (the center figure) has curly hair and a curly beard. He appears to be half- kneeling, with his right leg raised and bent at the knee, the bare right foot prominent. He is gowned and faces forward, to the left, and up, with his head bent back and eyes raised. His arms are not pictured (see the right arm and hand position of Eliphaz, the front-most figure).

Job's three friends sit or kneel lower right. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, these are, from right to left, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. The last, the friend furthest to the left, is partly obscured by Bildad; consequently, it is unclear whether Zophar is sitting or kneeling. He is gowned and bearded. He faces forward and to the left.

illustration.illusobjdesc: God appears at the top of the design. He reaches down with his left arm, much like the figure on the frontispiece to Europe, and points toward the circle or sphere in which are pictured Behemoth and Leviathan. God appears to lean on a cloud band that fills the night sky. Winged and gowned angels in attitudes of prayer frame the upper left and right portion of the design. The cloud band descends behind the angels and stops at the halfway point of the circle or sphere in the lower portion of the design. Job, his wife, and three friends kneel on the ground between God and the beastly sphere and look down toward it. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, they are, from right to left, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. The creatures within the circle or sphere are accompanied by reeds (some with catkins) and a frothy wave of the sea in which Leviathan disports.

component.illusobjdesc: God—old, bearded, and with long hair—anchors the top portion. He faces forward, but we see only his shoulders, arms, and head. His body is obscured by the cloud band on which he leans with his bent right arm and the upper part of his left arm. The fingers of his right hand (which may be holding the cloud) are spread apart. He reaches downward with his left arm, in a gesture very similar to the figure's on the frontispiece to *Europe*, and points downward with his extended left index finger. No clothes are clearly indicated, although one of the lines on his right wrist may be a sleeve rather than hair extending from his beard. His eyes are turned sharply downward or possibly closed. The suffusion of light around God's head suggests a halo.
God leans on a band of clouds which descends in an arc behind the attending angels and extends downward on each side of the circle or sphere to its mid-point.
Bare earth(?) below Job, his wife, and friends, separates them from the sphere in the lower portion of the design and extends on both sides and below the sphere.

Two hovering angels, winged and gowned, frame God in the upper portion of the design. The angel on the left has short curly hair and faces to the right, with his arm bent at the elbow. His hands are together in prayer; his fingertips touch his chin. His lower right leg and foot are visible among the drapery trailing from his gown.

Two hovering angels, winged, gowned, frame God in the upper portion of the design. The angel on the right has long, curly hair and faces to the left, with his left arm bent at the elbow and his lower arm raised in prayer; his fingertips touch his chin. His lower left leg and foot are visible among the drapery trailing from his gown.

Job's wife sits or kneels in a contracted posture just to the left of her husband. She is gowned and has long hair; her upper body leans forward and she faces to the right. Her arms are crossed over her chest. Her eyes are cast downward, probably to look at the beasts below.

Job—bearded, old, gowned, and with long hair—kneels or sits in a contracted posture just below the figure of God. He faces forward, down, and to the right, with his arms crossed over his chest. He is probably looking down at the beasts to which God points. The fingers on his left hand are spread apart in an unusual gesture, while the fingers of his right hand are spread apart.

Job's three friends kneel or sit just right of God's downward-reaching arm. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, they are, from right to left, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. All three may be looking, with downcast eyes, at the beasts below. Eliphaz leans forward, facing down and to the left, in a decidedly contracted posture. His left arm is bent sharply at the elbow, with his upper left arm close to his chest. His hair and beard are long; he is gowned. His left knee is prominent.

Job's three friends kneel or sit just right of God's downward-reaching arm. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, they are, from right to left, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. All three may be looking, with downcast eyes, at the beasts below. Bildad leans forward, facing down and to the left, in a decidedly contracted posture. We see only his bearded face and left knee. His hair is curly.

Job's three friends kneel or sit just right of God's downward-reaching arm. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, they are, from right to left, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. All three may be looking, with downcast eyes, at the beasts below. Zophar leans forward, facing down and to the left, in a decidedly contracted posture. We see his bearded face and both of his knees.
The great beasts, Behemoth and Leviathan, are pictured within a circle, perhaps to be understood as a cross-section of a sphere or globe.

Behemoth is the upper-most of the two biblical beasts pictured within a circle or globe. He stands, or possibly strides, facing left, with his head turned partly forward. We can see Behemoth’s muscles and tendons, as though the creature lacked skin. His large left ear is anthropomorphic; large teeth or tusks extend from his partly-open mouth. His vertebral column is clearly enunciated, along with his ribs and tail. Hair is discernible on his face and the end of his tail.

Leviathan is the lower of the two biblical beasts pictured within a circle or globe. He is a giant sea-serpent with two sets of large fangs and additional rows of smaller fang-like teeth filling his partly-open mouth. His crested head faces up, while his scaly, and intermittently spiky body loops to the left.

Reeds with catkins frame Behemoth on the right and left. To the right of Leviathan's crested head, there appear to be rough outlines of reeds and other indeterminate types of vegetation. The blades below Behemoth's belly suggest more reeds in the background.
Behemoth stands on marshy or sandy ground, perhaps on the shore of the sea in which Leviathan wreathes.
Leviathan wreathes in the sea. A frothy wave breaks just below him.
The night sky surrounding the upper portion of the watercolor includes sixteen(?) stars.

illustration.illusobjdesc: God sits at the top in the center. The faint outlines of what may be putti or cherubs surround him. He holds an open book on his lap; he raises his right hand, palm out, in a sign of blessing. Radiance and beams of light surround him, and cloud bands on the right and left encircle him. Two large angels hover nearby, right and left. Tongues of flame contain a vision of Satan falling headlong with bolts of lightning into the fires of hell below. The two figures with him have been variously identified as his fellow-devils and as the fallen selves of Job (right) and his wife (left). On the ground lower left, Job and his wife sit or kneel, beholding the vision in the flame. The foreground beneath Job and his wife appears to be grassy or mossy. Behind and to the right of Job's wife is a grassy hill. They are on the edge of a cliff that drops off sharply to the right of the figures, and from which issues the fires of hell. Job's three friends kneel, aghast at the vision, lower right. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, these are Zophar (left-most in the group, seen from behind), Bildad (head only, upper right), and Eliphaz (nearest the lower right corner of the design).

component.illusobjdesc: God sits at the top in the center of the design. He is surrounded by the faint outlines of cherubs or putti. He holds an open book on his lap, and raises his right hand, palm out and fingers spread, in a sign of blessing. He is old, with long hair and beard, and wears a flowing gown. He faces forward, but leans and looks to the left. Beams of light and radiance illuminate the area behind God. His knees are prominent.
God holds an open book on his lap.
God sits enthroned on a plinth or at the top of (three?) steps.

The faint outlines of what may be three angels, putti, or cherubs hover to the left of God. Only their heads and, in the case of the lower two forms, perhaps their upper bodies, are visible. These figures appear to be facing right, towards God.

The faint outlines of what may be three angels, putti, or cherubs hover to the right of God. Only the head(?) of the uppermost form is visible. The head, upper body, and wing of the middle angel can be discerned, while only the head and wing of the lower angel are visible. These figures appear to be facing left, towards God.
God sits, apparently enthroned, at the top of the image. The area behind him is aglow with radiance; beams of light radiate outward, although occluded by clouds or smoke.

A large, winged and gowned angel hovers in the left margin. His body faces to the right, with his head turned toward us. His hair is long and curly. His right arm is bent upward, with the fingers of his right hand slightly spread. The gesture suggests prayer even though the other hand is not visible. His bare right foot is visible among the drapery of his gown.

A large winged and gowned angel hovers in the right margin. His right leg is bent at the knee and his body faces away from the viewer. His head is turned to the left and slightly down. His hair is long, and his bare feet are visible among the drapery of his gown.
Large tongues of flame appear below God; within them is a vision of Satan and two other figures (possibly Job and his wife).

Bolts of lightning appear below and on the left and right sides of the large tongues of flame below God. Below these are three more flames (of hell?) that issue upward between cliffs—or possibly the sides of a cave extending down to hell.
The area between the falling figures and the lower flames appears to be filled with smoke.

A vision of Satan appears as the central figure in the large tongue of flame below God. The two figures with him have been variously identified as his fellow devils and as the fallen forms of Job (right) and his wife (left). All three are falling upside down into the abyss. The figure on the left has her(?) head down, with her arms bent at the elbows and her hands clutching her head. She is seen from behind; her hair is long. Her legs are bent sharply at the knees and pulled up behind her torso; both feet are prominent. She is probably gowned, although there is little in the way of clear evidence of clothing other than traces of what may be diaphanous drapery over her buttocks.

A vision of Satan appears as the central figure in the large tongue of flame below God. The two figures with him have been variously identified as his fellow devils and as the fallen forms of Job (right) and his wife (left). All three are falling upside down into the abyss. Satan is seen from the front, with his arms bent behind his head. His mouth is open, perhaps in an expression of pain. His left leg is extended; the left foot is prominent. His right leg is bent at the knee. His nude body is slightly twisted.

A vision of Satan appears as the central figure in the large tongue of flame below God. The two figures with him have been variously identified as his fellow devils and as the fallen forms of Job (right) and his wife (left). All three are falling upside down into the abyss. The figure on the right has his head down, with at least his right arm bent over his head. Both arms may be wrapped around his head. He is seen from behind; his hair is long. His legs are bent at the knees and pulled up toward his torso; both feet are prominent. A few lines suggest that his twisted body is gowned.
Job and his wife sit on a plot of ground that descends sharply, like the edge of a cliff, just right of the two figures. The outline of a low hill rises behind them.
Grass or moss grows around and behind Job and his wife in the lower left corner.
Green tinting suggests grass below and to the left of Job’s friends in the lower right corner.
Job's three friends appear to be sitting on a plot of ground in the lower right corner. The ground falls off sharply on the left, like a cliff.

Job sits or kneels lower left. He is old, with long hair and a beard. He faces forward and to the right, with his head turned upward to view the vision in the large, central flame. He is partly nude, with his rough cloth draped over his loins and legs. His arms are at his side, with his hands down, palms facing down and fingers spread. This gesture suggests surprise. His lips may be slightly parted.

Job's wife sits or kneels, lower left, just right of her husband. She is gowned, with long hair and her lips slightly parted. Her arms are crossed over her chest, with the fingers of both hands slightly spread. She faces forward, with her head bent back to view the vision in the large, central flame.

Job's three friends huddle, in twisted postures, in the lower right corner. Given our identification of the friends in Object 7, they are Zophar (left), Eliphaz (lower right), and Bildad (just above Eliphaz). Zophar is gowned; his hair is long and his left foot is prominent. He may be kneeling. We see him from behind, with his body twisted to the right and his head twisted to the left. He appears to be looking up at the vision in the large, central flame. His mouth is slightly open; he appears to be amazed or frightened by the vision.

Job's three friends huddle, in twisted postures, in the lower right corner. Given our identification of the friends in Object 7, they are Zophar (left), Eliphaz (lower right), and Bildad (just above Eliphaz). Eliphaz is bearded and gowned; his hair may be long. He sits or kneels, with his body facing to the right and his head twisted back to the left and up, to view the vision in the large, central flames. His right arm is bent over his chest, with his right hand reaching upward toward (or perhaps just touching) his face. The position of his left arm is unclear; it may be hidden beneath his flowing beard.

Job's three friends huddle, in twisted postures, in the lower right corner. Given our identification of the friends in Object 7, they are Zophar (left), Eliphaz (lower right), and Bildad (just above Eliphaz). We see only the head of Bildad; he is bearded and his hair is curly. His head is turned upward to view the vision in the large, central flame.

illustration.illusobjdesc: God stands on the left, his arms raised to bless Job and his wife who kneel before him, their hands clasped in prayer. Behind them are Job's three friends; they cover their faces as though hiding from his might, indicated by the great burst of radiance forming a halo around his head and shooting out pointed beams of light. The background on the right contains a hill or mountain.

component.illusobjdesc: God—old, gowned and magisterial—stands on the left and leans forward to reach down and bless Job and his wife. His hair and beard are long. He faces to the right, with his arms raised horizontally and the fingers of his hands spread apart. His bare right foot is prominent. A great burst of radiance with pointed beams of light forms a halo around God's head and upper body and extends to the left and right margins.
A cloud curves in from the left margin and extends across and below the left edge of the hem of God's garment.
A great burst of radiance with pointed beams of light forms a halo around God's head and upper body and extends toward the left and right margins.

Job's wife sits or kneels just to the right of God. She is gowned and has long hair. She faces left, with her head turned a bit toward the viewer. Her arms are bent at the elbows, with her hands together in prayer. Her eyes are raised toward God.

Job sits or kneels under God's hands. He is old and bearded and has long hair; his rough cloth is draped over his thighs, lap, and left hip. His arms are down, with his hands joined in an attitude of prayer. He faces to the left and forward, with his eyes raised towards God.

Job's three gowned friends huddle together in contracted postures, apparently surprised or frightened by God's presence. They sit or squat, with their backs turned away from God so that they face to the right. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, these are, from lowest to highest, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. Eliphaz’s lower body faces forward and to the left, with his left knee prominent, but twists his upper body and head sharply to the right. His right arm is bent upward and his head is down; he grasps the top of his head with his right hand.

Job's three gowned friends huddle together in contracted postures, apparently surprised or frightened by God's presence. They sit or squat, with their backs turned away from God so that they face to the right. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, these are, from lowest to highest, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. Bildad hunches over with his body facing to the right and his head down. His hair is curly.

Job's three gowned friends huddle together in contracted postures, apparently surprised or frightened by God's presence. They sit or squat, with their backs turned away from God so that they face to the right. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, these are, from lowest to highest, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. Zophar hunches over and faces to the right, with his head down. His hair may be short.
The background on the right includes hills or mountains.

desc.related: This pencil drawing of the back of a figure’s head, preparatory for the engravings, is related to the back of Job’s head in Object 18 in the Linnell series of water colors.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job stands, with his back to us, before a stone altar, above which rises a triangular or heart-shaped flame. His cruciform posture, with arms extended a little above the horizontal, suggests a self-sacrifice. Job's wife kneels on the left; his three friends kneel with heads bowed on the right. Smoke rises into the sky from the sacrifice; in the left middle distance is a structure composed of three pillars and a heavy horizontal stone. In background on the left are more ruins, while a mountain, possibly with a river or lake below it, defines the horizon on the right.

component.illusobjdesc: Job stands, with his back to us, before a stone altar, above which rises a heart-shaped flame. His cruciform posture, with arms extended a little above the horizontal, suggests a self-sacrifice Job is giving to his God and perhaps a type of spiritual ecstasy. He is gowned and bearded, and has long hair. The fingers of his extended hands (palms facing down and out) are spread apart. His right leg is slightly bent and extended a bit behind him, with his right foot balanced on tiptoe. His head is turned to the left and tilted upward. His right heel and the flowing hem of his garment are prominent.

Job's wife kneels in prayer just left of her husband. She is gowned and has long hair. She faces away and to the right, with her head bowed and eyes closed. Her arms are bent upward with her right hand near her face. Her left hand is not pictured, but her posture and gestures suggest that her hands are together in prayer. Her bare feet are prominent, as is the hem of her garment.

Job's three friends kneel lower right. Their postures are somewhat contracted as they bend forward with heads down. Like Job’s wife, they may be praying. We see them from behind; the soles of their feet visible beneath their gowns. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, they are Bildad (the leftmost figure, individuated by his curly hair) and Eliphaz and Zophar to the right of Bildad. The representations of Eliphaz and Zophar are in this design insufficient to discriminate between them. Bildad’s left arm may be bent upward at the elbow.

Job’s three friends kneel lower right. Like Job's wife, they may be praying. Their postures are somewhat contracted as they bend forward with heads down. We see them from behind, the soles of their feet visible beneath their gowns. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, they are Bildad (the leftmost figure, individuated by his curly hair) and Eliphaz and Zophar to the right of Bildad. The representations of Eliphaz and Zophar are in this design insufficient for discrimination between them. The middle figure has long hair, while the hair of the figure farthest right may be shorter.
A large stone altar stands behind Job.

A large, triangular or heart-shaped flame rises from the altar behind Job. Smoke from the fire or a large cloud appears on each side of the heart-shaped flame. This is probably a burning sacrifice Job is offering to his God.

Green washes indicate grass on the ground below the figures. The ground rises into a hill on the left, in the middle distance behind Job's wife. A higher hill or mountain appears behind the most distant ruins.
On the hilltop in the left middle distance is a (stone?) colonnade with three pillars. Fragments of other pillars rise on the hill in the far distance.
A mountain rises in the background on the right, with clouds above it. The white strip below the mountain may be a river or lake.

desc.objtitle: Every Man also Gave Him a Piece of Money, Object 19 (Butlin 551.19)
desc.related: This pencil drawing, preparatory for the engravings, is a variant design for the same subject as Object 19 in the Linnell series of water colors.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job and his wife sit on the right. His left arm crosses his chest as he holds his upper right arm with his left hand. His left hand is on his knee. His wife crosses her arms over her breasts. Green washes indicate grass on the ground below and between the figures. A fig tree, bearing fruit, rises to the right of Job; behind Job and his wife are broken stones, perhaps columns or part of a wall. Four standing figures on the left are bringing charitable gifts to the now-humbled couple. These figures are, from left to right, a young woman holding a net-like purse containing gold(?) coins; another young woman, partly obscured by her companion; a tall, bearded man holding a purse or covered vessel of some sort; and a woman with a scarf over her head who holds, in her extended left hand, a circular-and-diamond-shaped object, perhaps jewelry. Grain stems with tassels and a distant mountain rise between the two groups of figures.

component.illusobjdesc: Job sits on the right, his head humbly bowed. He is bearded and gowned, with his bare left foot extended beyond the flowing hem of his garment. His hair is long. His left arm is bent at the elbow and extended across his chest, with his left hand resting on, or perhaps holding, his upper right arm. His right arm is extended along his leg, with his right hand resting on his knee. He faces to the left.

Job's wife sits just to the left of her husband. Her head is humbly bowed, with her eyes lowered and at least partly closed. She is gowned, has long hair, and faces to the left and down. Her arms are crossed over her breast.

The left-most youthful female standing in the group of four figures approaching Job and his wife has curly hair that is tied up in some sort of bun. She is gowned and faces to the right. Her arms are bent over her torso. She holds a net purse containing gold(?) coins in the spread fingers of her lowered left hand.

The left-most female standing in the group of four figures holds a net purse containing gold(?) coins in her left hand with her index finger curled. The opening of the purse may be held in her right hand. Some of the coins fall below her left hand and into the bottom of the purse.

The young female standing second from the left (in the group of four figures approaching Job and his wife) is partly obscured by her companion to the left. She is gowned and her curly hair may be long or tied into a bun. She faces forward and to the right.

The man standing second from the right (in the group of four figures approaching Job and his wife) holds a vase or urn with a triangular top in both hands. His right arm is bent at the elbow. He has a beard, short and curly hair, a gown, and sandals on his prominent feet. He faces forward and to the right, with his right leg drawn a little behind his left. He is probably walking to the right. His posture suggests that he is about to give something from the container to Job and his wife.

The man in the group of four figures approaching Job and his wife holds a triangular object, probably a vase or container of some sort. This object has sometimes been described as a purse, but it clearly has a small finial at its top. This motif suggests that it is a covered jar, vase, or bowl rather than a purse. The container is decorated with a standing angel, winged and gowned. The angel is probably facing left and may be striding in that direction. This figure may be a personification of a healing balm within the container.

The right-most figure (in the group of four standing figures approaching Job and his wife) is a young woman who holds, in her extended left hand (palm out), a circular-and-diamond shaped object, perhaps jewelry. She is probably about to give this to Job's wife. She faces forward and to the right, and wears a scarf over her long hair. Her shod left foot extends from the hem of her gown, suggesting she may be walking.

The right-most figure (in the group of four standing figures approaching Job and his wife) is a young woman who holds, in her extended left hand, a circular-and-diamond shaped object. This is probably a piece of jewelry, perhaps a pendant of some sort or possibly a large earring.

Job and his wife may be sitting on a grassy mound, one that extends just right of Job's left hip. However, just above and to the left of his wife's right knee is a stepped object, possibly made of stone, that suggests a seat or bench.
A large fig tree grows right of Job and spreads is leafy and fruit-bearing limbs along the top margin.
Green washes indicate grass on the ground below and between the figures. The color also extends over the bank(?) right of Job's lower body.
Grain stems with tassels stand between the two groups of figures.
A distant mountain appears below the extended left arm of the rightmost woman in the group of four figures on the left. Washes in the sky suggest clouds, possibly at sunrise or sunset.
A ruined wall (or perhaps a broken pillar on the left with a wall extending from it on the right) backs Job and his wife.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job, the aged, bearded, long-haired patriarch, sits with his three daughters (two at his side, one kneeling before him) in the center of the design. His arms are raised horizontally to point out the pictures on the wall behind him. A rectangular wall picture appears above Job's head, with circular pictures behind his hands right and left. All three would appear to be rough sketches representing scenes in Job's own life. The rows of pictures show, from left to right, figures fleeing from a figure who is attacking them with a pole or a spear; a circle over two additional circles; and another figure who may be bent backwards in a painful manner. The foreground is adorned with grass. A horned ram and sleeping dog lie prone in the lower left corner of the design. In the opposite (right) lower corner, there are two more prone sheep, and the sheep closest to Job’s kneeling daughter is asleep.

component.illusobjdesc: Job and his three daughters sit before a stone(?) wall, which contains representational sketches. The ground before the wall is grassy.

Job—aged, bearded, gowned, and long haired—sits in the center of the design. Three members of his family—all daughters—sit or kneel around him. He faces forward with his arms raised horizontally. His extended hands, fingers slightly spread, point to the sketches on the walls. The palms of his raised hands face down. His legs are spread apart, with his bare right foot partly exposed beneath the flowing hem of his garment. His knees are also prominent.

One of Job's daughters sits just to the left of her father. She is gowned, with legs together and knees prominent (as is the ruffled hem of her garment). Her arms are bent upward and her hands crossed over her breasts. Her right hand lightly touches her father's upper right leg. She faces forward, with her head turned a bit to the right. Her eyes are raised and her hair is long and slightly curly.

One of Job's daughters sits just to the right of her father. She is gowned, with legs together and knees prominent (as is the ruffled hem of her garment). Both arms are bent, and her hands are clasped together between her prominent knees. She faces forward with her eyes raised and her head turned a bit to the left. Her hair is long and slightly curly.

One of Job's daughters kneels in front of her father. We see her from behind, but her head is twisted to the left and down. Her hair is long and appears to be held back into a bun. The flowing hem of her garment is prominent.

The wall sketch on the left includes two figures that might be fleeing in fear from their attackers on the right. One (or both) of the figures may have its arm raised horizontally as it runs to the left of the circular sketch. Below the two figures there might be additional outlines of indeterminate objects.

The wall sketch within the circular frame on the left includes two figures that might be fleeing in fear from their attackers(?) on the right. An outline of a figure holding a pole or a spear appears to be chasing the two fleeing figures. There may be two(?) additional figures; however, they are depicted as circles only, which may represent their heads(?).
An outlined figure (right) on the leftmost wall sketch may be attacking its victims with a long pole or spear(?).

The wall sketch within the rectangular frame above Job’s head contains circular forms, probably representing a hovering figure (with extended arms?) and, below, two crouching figures facing each other with heads bowed.

In the right wall sketch, there is an outline of a figure (lower right corner) bent over backwards, while holding an object. The back of its head is directly above Job’s left palm. The outline of the figure's nose is prominent as he faces up towards the lines above and to the left. He may be holding a large object angled downward toward the lower right. Some of these lines vaguely suggest a figure hovering in the sky.

A rectangular (stone?) object projects to the left just left of the lower right leg of Job's daughter seated to the left of him. This may be a corner of the plinth or seat on which all three figures are placed.

A rectangular (stone?) object projects to the right just left of the lower left leg of Job's daughter seated to the right of him. This may be a corner of the plinth or seat on which all three figures are placed.
Grass appears in the foreground.
Behind the sleeping dog (lower left corner) lies a ram with looped horns. It faces forward towards the viewer.
fur
There is a shaggy, sleeping dog curled up in the grass in the lower left corner. Its eyes are closed.
In the lower right corner, a sheep lies on the grass with its legs tucked underneath its body as it sleeps.
Just right of the sleeping sheep, another sheep lies facing the viewer.

desc.objtitle: Job and His Family Restored to Prosperity, Object 21 (Butlin 551.21)
desc.related: This sketch, preparatory for the engravings, may be related, albeit distantly, to the foliage on the large central tree in Objects 1 and 21 in the Linnell series of water colors.

These sketches, preparatory for the engravings, may be related to the dog with its head resting on the ground in the center foreground in Object 21 in the Linnell series of water colors or to the dog with its head resting on a sheep in the center foreground of Object 1 in the Linnell series of water colors.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The final design mirrors the first (Object 1), but with significant differences. Job's family, restored and reunited, stand and sing or play musical instruments. From left to right they are a youthful male playing double pipes; two of his brothers playing horns; another young son playing a curled horn; a youthful daughter holding a scroll and possibly singing; Job's wife playing a mandolin; a young daughter holding a scroll (possibly another musical score) and perhaps singing; Job playing a large triangular harp; a young female playing a lyre; a son playing a curled horn and another playing a large harp; and a final youthful male holding a pipe, his mouth open, perhaps in song. The instruments hung in the tree in the first scene of the drama are now used to praise God. The great (oak?) tree from the opening scene again anchors the middle of the design; a sun appears over a distant mountain range on the right, and a crescent moon and one star (or planet) appear in the sky on the left. Six sheep, including one ram, and a dog lie on grass in the foreground. Two sheep appear behind the legs of the figures.

component.illusobjdesc: Job's family, restored and reunited, stand and sing or play musical instruments. The patriarch stands, playing a large triangular harp, on the right side of the central tree. He is gowned and bearded; his hair is long and his lips are slightly parted. He may be singing. He faces forward with his eyes looking upward, his left arm raised at 135 degrees, and his left hand possibly pointing to the heavens. His right arm is bent across his body, with the fingers of his right hand (slightly spread) placed on the strings of the harp. His bare right foot extends beyond the hem of his gown.

The figure furthest to the left is a young male, one of Job's sons. He is gowned and standing, facing forward and to the right, with his left leg drawn slightly behind his right. His hair is curly and short. His arms are bent at the elbow and he holds two pipes on which he plays with spread fingers.

The second figure from the left is a youthful male, one of Job's sons, playing a horn. What little we see of his hair suggests that it is curly. He is gowned and standing, with his left arm raised at 135 degrees to hold his horn in his left hand. His head is bent back slightly, with his body facing to the right and his head facing a little up. His bare right foot is prominent beneath the hem of his gown.

The third figure from the left is a youthful male wearing a short gown or perhaps tights. This young man, one of Job's sons, plays a horn. He is standing, with his left leg slightly bent and his left foot behind his right and poised on tiptoe. His head is bent back slightly, with his body facing forward and to the right and his head facing up. His left arm is raised at 135 degrees to hold the large horn.

The fourth figure from the left is a youthful male, one of Job's sons, playing a horn with loops that suggest a spiral. He wears tights, or perhaps a short gown. He is standing, with his right leg slightly bent and his right foot behind his left and poised on tiptoe. He faces forward and to the right, with his head and eyes inclined downward. His right arm is bent upward to hold his horn.

The fifth figure from the left is a young female, one of Job's daughters. She is gowned, with her hair long and perhaps drawn up into a bun. She is standing, facing forward and to the left. Her arms are at her sides and she holds a scroll or manuscript, perhaps of music in her hands. Her lips are slightly parted, indicating that she may be singing. Her left foot extends from under the hem of her garment.

Job's wife stands on the left side of the central tree, the sixth figure from the left. She faces forward, holding and playing (with fingers spread) a mandolin. She is gowned, with her left foot extending from under the hem of her garment. Her bent right hand is lowered onto the strings of the instrument. Her hair is long and her head and eyes are inclined slightly upward and to the right.

A young female stands in front of the central tree and between Job and his wife. She faces forward with her head bent upward and slightly to the left and her eyes raised. She is one of Job's daughters. She is gowned and has long, curly hair. Both feet emerge just beyond the ruffled hem of her garment. Her slightly bent arms extend outward from her sides, and she holds in her hands a scroll or manuscript, perhaps of music. The fingers of her right hand are spread. Although her mouth is not open, she may be singing.

The figure furthest to the right in the family group is a young male, one of Job's sons, with long hair. He wears tights and stands with his right knee slightly bent and his right foot drawn back and on tiptoe. He faces to the left, with head bent back and eyes raised, and holds a pipe in both hands. His mouth is slightly open; he may be playing the pipe (although not at this moment) or singing. His right arm is bent upward and his right hand holds the pipe. His right hand, like the left, is on the pipe.

The second figure from the right is a young male, one of Job's sons, who stands facing forward and to the left. He holds, and plays upon, a large harp. He wears tights and has his right leg drawn behind his left. His right arm is bent upward to play the harp with fingers spread. He is bearded and has short, curly hair. His lips are slightly parted; he may be singing.

The figure third from the right is a young male, one of Job's sons, who faces forward with his head bent back and eyes raised. He wears tights; the curved horn he holds and plays has a small loop near the mouthpiece. His right arm is bent upward to hold the horn. His hair is short.

The figure fourth from the right (and standing just right of Job) is a young female, one of Job's daughters, facing forward and to the right. She is gowned and has long hair. She holds a lyre in her left hand and plays upon its strings with the spread fingers of her right hand. Her mouth is slightly open; she may be singing. Her right arm is bent horizontally across her body.
Two sheep can be seen behind the standing figures, right and left. The right sheep is lying prone to the ground, while the left sheep is grazing.
Green washes indicate grass on the ground below the figures and below the sheep.

Five sheep, a ram, and a dog lie prone in the foreground. All three animals on the right are facing left; the dog, and possibly the sheep in the middle of the group, are asleep. The four sheep on the left include at least two that may be sleeping. The bodies of three in the group face right; the head of the left-most sheep faces forward.
A large tree—probably an oak—with a heavy trunk stands in the center of the design. Its leaves spread out along the top margin.
The top lip of a mountain range appears above the figures on the left. In the sky above is a crescent moon and a star or planet (possibly Venus, given the rising sun on the right).

The top lip of a mountain range appears above the figures on the right. The disc of the sun appears just above the mountains; its radiance and beams of light fill the sky above. The sun is inscribed with words quoted from Revelation 15:3; see the textual transcription. Given the joyous nature of the design, this surely must be a rising (rather than setting) sun.
Words quoted from Revelation 15:3 are inscribed within the disc of the sun, upper right; see the textual transcription.

lg.l: Great & MarvellousLines 1-2 are written in ink within the small portion of the sun's disc appearing just above the distant mountains on the right. They appear to have been written over (but offset from) the same, or very similar, words very lightly written in pencil. The faint pencil marks extending beyond the final word in line 1, as transcribed here, may be another word in this under-writing, but it is not legible.

are thy Works LordThe letter "O", written in ink, appears under the first two letters of the final word. An ink line curling upward after the final word transcribed here may be an attempt to obscure an original "L" which, like "O," had been lightly written in ink over pencil. Blake may have first written "O Lord" in pencil, then written over the "O" and "L" in ink. When he added "Lord" in darker ink over the "O," he may have tried to obscure the top of the "L" by adding a flourish to the "d" of "Lord" in dark ink.
